start/stop firewall is in /etc/init.d/uf: using vi that's "vi +10" to start on 10th line. However guido is gone by now I see.
what is the utf actuelly? Im supposed to make a script for iptables in school soo I want the script to work on diffrent computers
ufw is the 'naming' of the firewall rules. It actually starts iptables rules, see configs in /etc/default/ufw and of course /etc/ufw/* files
so what i actuelly should do when it says stop iptables services Is that I would flush all rules?
if stopped, then all rules are 'flushed' - if that's what you're asking?
at any given time you can see the 'active' rules by "sudo iptables -L"
yeah but I guess that ubuntu always has IPtables enabled, So if I would have a control in my script thats says "stop iptables service" it would actuelly just flush all rules
not stop the service couse there is none
I don't think I understand the question. The /etc/init.d/ufw is the controlscript (or 'service') for iptables firewall
the kernel module iptable_filter stays loaded, all rules are flushed, leaving your system unprotected
indeed. The 'stop' argument to ufw script does actually an flush, a delete (-F, -X) on existing chains and set policy to ACCEPT.

So when the project paper says that my script should support <Turning on/off packet fultering> then it just meas that i shuld flush all rules? But that wouldnt do because then I woulnt be able to turn it back on
turning on/off *does* mean the capability of flushing rules. Flushing does *not* mean removing your definitions in the configuration file, but (re)setting the actual state of the active rules/chains
so i change ACCEPT On of for a specific rule/chain
